problem.tex: Let $u$ be a positive harmonic function over the punctured plane $\mathbb{C}\setminus\{0\}$. Show that $u$ must be constant.

solution.tex: Look at the composition map $U:\mathbb{C}\to[0,\infty)$, \[\mathbb{C}\xrightarrow{\exp}\mathbb{C}\setminus\{0\}\xrightarrow{u}[0,\infty).\] Precomposing a harmonic function with a holomorphic function gives a harmonic function. This can be computed directly using the Cauchy-Riemann equations, https://math.stackexchange.com/questions/151827/composition-of-a-harmonic-function-with-a-holomorphic-function-is-still-harmonic. Now we answer a simpler question: show any nonnegative harmonic function $U$ defined on all of $\mathbb{C}$ must be constant. Recall Harnack's inequality, it is stated below for a ball of radius $R$ centered at the origin and a point $re^{i\theta}$ in the ball. \[\frac{R-r}{R+r}U(0)\leq U(re^{i\theta})\leq\frac{R+r}{R-r}U(0).\] Letting $R\to\infty$ gives that $U(0)=U(re^{i\theta})$, so $U$ is constant. In this problem, $U=u\circ\exp$ and $\exp$ is surjective, so $U$ being constant forces $u$ to be constant.
